fields.name: Dissociative Experiences Scale Taxon (DES-T)
fields.citation: Carlson, E.B. & Putnam, F.W. (1993). An update on the Dissociative Experience Scale. Dissociation 6(1), p. 16-27.
fields.description: This questionnaire consists of eight questions about the experiences you have had in your daily life. We are interested in how often you have had these experiences. It is important, however, that your answers show how often these experiences happen to you when you are not under the influence of alcohol or drugs. To answer the questions, please determine to what degree the experience described in the question applies to you and select the appropriate number to show what percentage of the time you have had the experience.

fields.name: International Trauma Questionnaire (ITQ)
fields.citation: Cloitre, M., Shevlin M., Brewin, C.R., Bisson, J.I., Roberts, N.P., Maercker, A., Karatzias, T., Hyland, P. (2018). The International Trauma Questionnaire: Development of a self-report measure of ICD-11 PTSD and Complex PTSD. Acta Psychiatrica Scandinavica. DOI: 10.1111/acps.12956

fields.name: STEP Screening Forms
fields.description: By providing your unique identifier and group leader's name on this form, you understand that while we make every effort to protect your information, using digital systems may involve some small risks, such as accidental access or errors in transmission. The responses you provide will be sent to your group leader via email to ensure your clinician has the necessary information for your treatment. Your clinician will use the unique identifier to link your responses to your identity and provide personalized care. By continuing, you agree to how your information will be used, shared with your group leader, securely stored, and your anonymized data shared with protocol developers, Prepped 4 Learning Inc. While we take precautions to protect your data, we are not responsible for any issues such as unauthorized access, data transmission errors, or technical problems that may occur.

fields.name: PTSD Checklist for DSM-5 (PCL-5)
fields.citation: Weathers, F. W., Litz, B. T., Keane, T. M., Palmieri, P. A., Marx, B. P., & Schnurr, P. P. (2013). The PTSD Checklist for DSM-5 (PCL-5) â€“ Standard [Measurement instrument]. Available from  https://www.ptsd.va.gov/
fields.description:
Instructions:

Considering the event you have identified with the group leader,

Below is a list of problems that people sometimes have in response to a very stressful experience. Please read each problem carefully and then select one of the options to indicate how much you have been bothered by that problem in the past week. The options include not at all, a little bit, moderately, quite a bit, and extremely.

fields.name: Depression Anxiety Stress Scale (DASS-21)
fields.citation: Lovibond, S.H. & Lovibond, P.F. (1995). Manual for the Depression Anxiety & Stress Scales. (2nd Ed.) Sydney: Psychology Foundation.
fields.description:
Please read each statement and select the number 0, 1, 2, or 3 which indicates how much the statement applied to you over the past week. There are no right or wrong answers. Do not spend too much time on any statement.

The rating scale is as follows:

0 Did not apply to me at all - NEVER

1 Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time - SOMETIMES

2 Applied to me to a considerable degree, or a good part of the time - OFTEN

3 Applied to me very much, or most of the time - ALMOST ALWAYS

fields.name: General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSE)
fields.citation: Schwarzer, R., & Jerusalem, M. (1995). Generalized Self-Efficacy scale. In J. Weinman, S. Wright, & M. Johnston, Measures in health psychology: A user's portfolio. Causal and control beliefs (pp. 35-37). Windsor, UK: NFER-NELSON.
fields.description: Directions: Please select the appropriate response for each item below.
